questions.text: Which of the following is the most common benign tumor of the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cavernous hemangioma


 

Explanation:

Cavernous hemangioma is the most common benign tumor of the liver

 

Benign hepatic tumors : Cavernous hemangioma (most common) > focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) >hepatocellular adenoma (rare)

 

Cavernous hemangioma is the most common benign liver tumour.

It appears as a discrete red-blue, soft nodule less than 2 cm in diameter, commonly located in a subcapsular location.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and signs of hypovolemic shock. She has a history of long-term contraceptive pill use. Imaging studies reveal a large hepatic mass with evidence of haemorrhage. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes. What is the likely diagnosis based on her clinical presentation and medical history?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hepatic adenoma

 

Explanation:

Based on the patients gender, history of use of OCP and clinical presentation, she most likely has a hepatic adenoma

 

  • Hepatocellular adenoma is a benign neoplasm that typically occurs in young women.
  • Strong association with the use of oral contraceptives
    • Estrogen is known to promote the growth of hepatic adenomas by stimulating hepatocyte proliferation.
  • On imaging - well-circumscribed and encapsulated discrete mass, sometimes with associated hemorrhage - giving heterogenous appearance (fat+ hemorrhage) .
  • The molecular subtypes of hepatic adenoma based on bordeaux classification are
    • Hepatocyte nuclear factor 1-alpha (HNF1α)-inactivated hepatocellular adenoma which are multiple and presents in young patients
    • Inflammatory hepatocellular adenoma - Most common to present with hemorrhage
    • β-Catenin–activated hepatocellular adenoma

questions.text: A 25-year-old sexually active woman who has been on OCP for the past 4 years comes to the ER with severe abdominal pain and features of hypovolemic shock. Ultrasound reveals a large hemorrhagic hepatic mass and fluid in the peritoneum. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) β-Catenin–activated hepatocellular adenoma

Explanation :

  • The risk of malignant depends on the molecular subtypes :
    • (HNF1α)-inactivated hepatocellular adenoma- minimal risk
    • Inflammatory hepatocellular adenoma - moderate risk
    • β-Catenin–activated hepatocellular adenoma - high risk
  • β-Catenin-–activated hepatocellular adenoma is strongly associated with OCP and anabolic steroid use.
  • Resection is recommended for β-catenin–activated tumours and tumours that are 5 cm or larger due to the risk of malignant transformation and haemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions presents with a central stellate scar?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Focal Nodular Hyperplasia

 

Explanation:

Focal Nodular Hyperplasia is a benign, non-neoplastic lesion which presents with a central stellate scar and is most common in women. It occurs due to altered blood flow, which causes hyperplastic changes in hepatocytes.

It is usually asymptomatic and is incidentally seen on imaging.

questions.text: All of the following increases the risk of Hepatocellular carcinoma, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gilbert's Syndrome

Explanation:

Gilbert's Syndrome is a benign condition associated with mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and does not cause liver damage or increase the risk of HCC.

The most common risk factors are

  • Viral infections (chronic hepatitis B and hepatitis C)
  • Toxic (Alcohol (Option A)and Aflatoxins)
  • Metabolic (Diabetes and NASH (Option B), Hemochromatosis (Option C), Wilson's syndrome)
  • Immune-related (Primary biliary cirrhosis and autoimmune hepatitis)

questions.text:
A patient with a longstanding history of alcoholism is admitted with jaundice, abdominal distension & weight loss. A liver biopsy done during his previous admission showed the following changes, and suspicion of malignant transformation is raised now. Elevation of which of the following markers will support the differential?


	HepPar-1
	Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
	Glypican-3 (GPC3)
	CA 15-3
	Tissue polypeptide antigen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1,2 and 3

Explanation :

The following markers will be elevated in case of hepatocellular carcinoma :

  • HepPar-1 (Statement 1)
  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) (Statement 2)
  • Glypican-3 (GPC3) (Statement 3)
  • Neurotensin
  • Arginase-1
  • CA-19-9

 

Chronic liver disease with cirrhosis is the major cause of transformation into hepatocellular carcinoma, and some of the common causes are listed below :

  • Alcohol (as given in the above scenario)
  • Chronic hepatitis B & C
  • Metabolic diseases
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis
  • Aflatoxins from Aspergillus

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with progressive jaundice for the past 2 months. Initial investigations were done, and subsequent histopathological examination of liver biopsy showed changes consistent with hepatoblastoma. Which of the following additional biomarkers will be elevated in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) AFP (alpha-fetoprotein)

 

Explanation :

  • Alpha-fetoprotein will be elevated in a patient with hepatoblastoma.
  • Hepatoblastoma is the most common liver tumour of childhood. Activation of the Wnt signalling pathway is characteristic of hepatoblastoma, leading to nuclear β-catenin and increased expression of Wnt target genes such as glutamine synthetase in nearly all cases.
  • It is important to note that elevated AFP is not pathognomonic to hepatocellular carcinoma. Conditions where AFP is raised are listed below :

 

Malignancy

Non-malignant conditions
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Secondary liver metastasis
  • Nonseminomatous germ cell tumours
  • Yolk sac tumour
  • Neural tube defects
  • Ataxia telangiectasia

CA 19-9 and Neurotensin markers are elevated in Heptatocellular carcinoma. (Options A and C)

CEA is a tumor marker for colorectal carcinoma. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a genetic mutation associated with hereditary pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) BRCA1

 

Explanation :

BRCA 1 mutation is most commonly associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer in women, whereas PRSS1, SPINK1, and CFTR are linked to hereditary pancreatitis.

Hereditary Pancreatitis: Recurrent severe acute pancreatitis attacks, often beginning in childhood due to a defect that increases trypsin activity in the gut.

 

Gene

Features

PRSS1 (trypsinogen 1 gene) (Option B)
  • Most common cause for hereditary pancreatitis.
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance
  • Gain-of-function mutation make trypsin resistant to self-inactivation
  • Increased risk of developing chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic cancer.

SPINK1(Option C)
  • Autosomal recessive inheritance
  • Loss of function mutation encoding a trypsin inhibitor

CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) (Option D)
  • Loss of CFTR leads to abnormal secretions
  • Promote plugging and duct obstruction
  • Associated conditions: recurrent sinopulmonary infections, intestinal obstruction, diabetes, and male infertility.

CASR (Calcium-sensing receptor):
  • Mutation alters calcium concentrations and activates trypsin.

CTRC (Chymotrypsin C):
  • Responsible for protecting pancreas from trypsin-related injury.

CPA1 (Carboxypeptidase A1):
  • Acts as exopeptidase, regulating zymogen activation.

questions.text: Which of the following factors is most strongly associated with the development of acute pancreatitis in adult males?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Alcohol

Explanation :

  • Acute pancreatitis is characterized by abdominal pain, associated with excessive alcohol intake, pancreatic duct obstruction, genetic factors, trauma, medications, infections, hypercalcemia, and ischemia.
  • Common symptoms include epigastric pain radiating to the back, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting.
  • Microscopy reveals focal necrosis, acinar degeneration with neutrophilic infiltrates
  • Elevated plasma levels of lipase and CT abdomen suggestive edematous pancreas with peripancreatic stranding supports the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with a history of type-2 diabetes and hypertension presented to hospital with a 3 day history of generalized weakness, diffuse abdominal pain and altered mental status. Upon examination, her GCS was 10 with diffuse abdominal tenderness. Investigations showed elevated glucose, creatinine, lipase, and calcium levels. Histopathological examination suggests which of the following associated findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intracellular activation of enzymes

 

Explanation:

 The patient's clinical findings, including abdominal pain, elevated lipase, and calcium, with microscopic image findings, suggest hypercalcemia-induced acute pancreatitis due to intracellular enzyme activation, a morphological hallmark of pancreatitis.

  • Gross: Fat and parenchymal necrosis with saponification.

 

  • Microscopic: interstitial inflammation, edema, fat necrosis, vessel wall damage, and hemorrhage. (image).

Pancreatitis in a Patient with Interstitial Pneumonitis Treated with Steroids. An Autopsy Case. JOP : Journal of the pancreas. 12. 158-61. 10.6092/1590-8577/3346.   • Hypercalcemia Induced Acute Pancreatitis:
    • Increased calcium influx causes inappropriate activation of digestive enzymes with intracellular trypsin autoactivation causing acinar cell injury.
    • Elevated calcium levels are linked to encephalopathy and acute kidney failure.
    • Possible causes of hypercalcemia: malignancy, hyperparathyroidism, hypervitaminosis D, granulomatous diseases.

questions.text: A female patient presents with progressive jaundice and weight loss for the past six months. She also complains of low grade upper abdominal pain. Lab investigation revealed a random blood sugar of 320mg/dL and a raised serum Ig-G4 levels and a USG scan showed a mass like lesion over the head of pancreas. Based on these findings which of the following is the most likely finding in the histopathological examination ?

choices.text: Pleomorphic cuboidal to columnar epithelial cells
Necrotic changes in the acini and ducts
Swirling fibrosis with inflammation of veins

questions.solution:
Correct Answer : D)Swirling fibrosis with inflammation of veins

 

Explanation:

Based on the clinical presentation, history, raised blood glucose and serum Ig-G4, along with a mass-like lesion in the pancreas points towards Autoimmune pancreatitis and histopathological examination of the pancreatic specimen will show characteristic swirling/storiform fibrosis with inflammation of veins

 

Autoimmune pancreatitis

Types

Type 1 - IgG4 associated - common in adults

Type 2 - Non-IgG4 associated - common in younger age groups

Clinical features

Low grade Abdominal pain

Jaundice

Weight loss

Lab findings

Elevated IgG4 (except in type 2)

Elevated liver enzymes

Elevated pancreatic enzymes

Elevated blood sugar

USG

Diffuse enlargement of pancreas

Focal enlargement can be present mimicking a malignancy

Narrowing of pancreatic ducts

Histology

Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate predominantly made up of IgG4-positive plasma cells (except in type 2)

Swirling fibrosis (storiform fibrosis) and Obliterative phlebitis (inflammation of veins)

Treatment

Excellent response to steroids

Azathioprine for relapsing disease

 

Raised Ig-G4 and the characteristic histological appearance help differentiate autoimmune pancreatitis from carcinoma pancreas since they both present with almost similar clinical features, and a mass-like lesion can be seen while imaging both.

 

Pleomorphic cuboidal to columnar epithelial cells (Option A) are seen in carcinoma pancreas

 

Necrotic changes in the acini and ducts (Option B) are seen in acute necrotising pancreatitis

 

Honeycombing appearance with cuboidal epithelium (Option C) is seen in serous cystadenoma of the pancreas.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pancreatic cystic neoplasms is true?

choices.text: Mucinous cystic neoplasms (MCNs) occur predominantly in males.
Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs) have a risk of malignant transformation.
Mucinous cystic neoplasms typically have a central scar on imaging.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs) have a risk of malignant transformation.

Explanation:

Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs), especially those involving the main duct or mixed type, have a risk of malignant transformation.
